content.description:
Start in opposing sidepulls at head height.  Crank up to a poor left hand crimp, toe in hard and grab a slightly better right hand crimp.  Re-set and reach with the left hand to a good sidepull.  The crux next move can be done two ways, drive-by up and left with the right hand for the jug, or crimp a bad gaston and go with the left hand.  From the jug the moves ease off but your getting high.  Traverse right past Choss Training to get to the top. 

  Considered a difficult tick for the grade.
content.location: On the main wall of the area, just past the Diaphanous Boulder.  Look for sidepulls and chalk marking the start of this problem.  Descent walk right and around back to ground level.

content.description: There are a variety of right hand starting holds used for this one, probably attributing to the range of proposed grades from V10-V12. Apparently the lower hold broke, justifying the higher right hand start & stand start (seen in most videos online)? It definitely still goes from what is left down low (there's both a slopey pocket and a crimp), and doesn't feel unreasonable. Regardless, it's a sit start!Update (9/20): In the new Kehl/Wilder book, it's given V11 and stated to use the slopey pocket for your right hand.
Classic low angle face climbing up a left leaning crack / flake.  The first moves are probably the hardest, but best to be solid before going too high on this one.
content.protection: Probably best not to fall, but a pad can protect the start, and it's possible to step off onto the wall behind if necessary.  Descent, walk right off of Diaphanous boulder and step across onto a small boulder.  Continue straight on this boulder and it's possible to scramble down the low angle backside.
content.location: On the backside of the Diaphanous boulder, easiest to cut behind boulders from the upper Michael Kenyon Area.  It is also possible to approach on either side of the Diaphanous boulder.  Watch out the rock is quite slick on the approach.

content.description: Diaphanous is a classic Hueco testpiece climbing out a steep ironrock wall on incut crimps. Start on an obvious low incut and make a few moves to a dyno and a good flake. Finish up the V5 above.
content.location: Located in the Sign of the Choss area in a small alcove

content.description: Start matched in a nice hueco and make a big move up and left to another good hueco.  Set up and dyno up and right for a good jug and top out the easy finish.  Don't try any of the other crimps and small features on this problem as they'll break right off.
content.location: On the main wall of the area, just past the Diaphanous Boulder. Look for obvious Hueco's marking the start of this problem.  Just Right of Sign of Choss, and left of some small trees. Descent walk right and around back to ground level.

content.description:
Mainly known for the classic hard problems Terremer V15, Terre de Sienne V14, and Diaphanous Sea V12, this area also has a few OK moderates and a classic V1 Hershey's Symphony. 

  For a video of Dave Graham Climbing Terre De Sienne see climbingnarc.com/2007/12/viâ€¦
